According to the competition's site(please correct me if I'm wrong!)

Your =
application functions over a network, your program connects to
the GameMast=
er who picks the game that will be played and transmits
the game definition=
 to the program, the game is then played (some are
1,2, or more players) an=
d the GameMaster program decides a score at
the end of the game based on th=
e game rules.  Before your match you do
not know what game you will be play=
ing, and for the competition they
will add new games that haven't been rele=
ase so people can't just
program for all the different games.  During the w=
eeks of the
competition you are allows( and encouraged) to make changes to =
your
application for the next week's matches.  The play clock can vary from=

between 10 seconds and an hour.  This year they plan to have a pretty
larg=
e range of the clocks.  If you don't make a move the GameMaster
will for yo=
u, if you make an illegal move, the GameMaster will make a
move for you and=
 you get a score of 0 for the match.

So the short answer I believe is "Yes=
, it is plug and play.". :-)

Charles Tarun

On 4/20/06, Kenneth Stanley <k=
stanley@...> wrote:
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Joseph Reising=
er <joeraii@...> wrote:
> >
> > > Per NEAT, is there any training/evolution=
 that occurs prior to
> the
> > > competition, or do you basically start ev=
olving the population
> from
> > > scratch during the competition, once you=
 receive the rule set?
> >
> > After the spec is received, there is some am=
ount of time for
> initial
> > learning before the match commences. For now=
 we're just starting
> from
> > scratch. I'm not convinced that we can do a=
ny meaningful neural
> > network "pre-patterning" given our current archite=
cture. Eventually
> > we'd like to explore using SOMs for the input layer, =
and at that
> > point it definitely becomes an option though.
> >
>
> Sound=
s like this can be interesting but I'm also wondering a few
> details.  So =
let's say you get a spec, what exactly do you do next?
> Do you get to chan=
ge some code around or add a new fitness function or
> perhaps sensor/outpu=
t combos appropriate to that spec?  Or is it
> completley plug and play and=
 you have a totally generic architecture?
> Then you just sit and wait a fe=
w hundred generations for evolution to
> pop out with something?  It would =
be cool if it was totally plug and
> play, such that your platform could be=
 used by anyone to evolve any
> game spec right away with no further coding=
, but I'm not sure from
> what you say how it works exactly.
>
> ken
